  14. (**************************************************************************)

  16. (** Parsing of command line arguments.

  18.    This module provides a general mechanism for extracting options and
  19.    arguments from the command line to the program. For example:

  21. {[
  22.      let usage_msg = "append [-verbose] <file1> [<file2>] ... -o <output>"
  23.      let verbose = ref false
  24.      let input_files = ref []
  25.      let output_file = ref ""

  27.      let anon_fun filename =
  28.        input_files := filename::!input_files

  30.      let speclist =
  31.        [("-verbose", Arg.Set verbose, "Output debug information");
  32.         ("-o", Arg.Set_string output_file, "Set output file name")]

  34.      let () =
  35.        Arg.parse speclist anon_fun usage_msg;
  36.        (* Main functionality here *)
  37. ]}

  39.    Syntax of command lines:
  40.     A keyword is a character string starting with a [-].
  41.     An option is a keyword alone or followed by an argument.
  42.     The types of keywords are: [Unit], [Bool], [Set], [Clear],
  43.     [String], [Set_string], [Int], [Set_int], [Float], [Set_float],
  44.     [Tuple], [Symbol], [Rest], [Rest_all] and [Expand].

  46.     [Unit], [Set] and [Clear] keywords take no argument.

  48.     A [Rest] or [Rest_all] keyword takes the remainder of the command line
  49.     as arguments. (More explanations below.)

  51.     Every other keyword takes the following word on the command line
  52.     as argument.  For compatibility with GNU getopt_long, [keyword=arg]
  53.     is also allowed.
  54.     Arguments not preceded by a keyword are called anonymous arguments.

  56.    Examples ([cmd] is assumed to be the command name):
  57. -   [cmd -flag           ](a unit option)
  58. -   [cmd -int 1          ](an int option with argument [1])
  59. -   [cmd -string foobar  ](a string option with argument ["foobar"])
  60. -   [cmd -float 12.34    ](a float option with argument [12.34])
  61. -   [cmd a b c           ](three anonymous arguments: ["a"], ["b"], and ["c"])
  62. -   [cmd a b -- c d      ](two anonymous arguments and a rest option with
  63.                            two arguments)

  65.     [Rest] takes a function that is called repeatedly for each
  66.     remaining command line argument. [Rest_all] takes a function that
  67.     is called once, with the list of all remaining arguments.

  69.     Note that if no arguments follow a [Rest] keyword then the function
  70.     is not called at all whereas the function for a [Rest_all] keyword
  71.     is called with an empty list.
  72. *)

  74. [@@@alert unsynchronized_access
  75.     "The Arg module relies on a mutable global state, parsing functions should \
  76.      only be called from a single domain."
  77. ]

  79. ‌type spec =
  80.   | Unit of (unit -> unit)     (** Call the function with unit argument *)
  81.   | Bool of (bool -> unit)     (** Call the function with a bool argument *)
  82.   | Set of bool ref            (** Set the reference to true *)
  83.   | Clear of bool ref          (** Set the reference to false *)
  84.   | String of (string -> unit) (** Call the function with a string argument *)
  85.   | Set_string of string ref   (** Set the reference to the string argument *)
  86.   | Int of (int -> unit)       (** Call the function with an int argument *)
  87.   | Set_int of int ref         (** Set the reference to the int argument *)
  88.   | Float of (float -> unit)   (** Call the function with a float argument *)
  89.   | Set_float of float ref     (** Set the reference to the float argument *)
  90.   | Tuple of spec list         (** Take several arguments according to the
  91.                                    spec list *)
  92.   | Symbol of string list * (string -> unit)
  93.                                (** Take one of the symbols as argument and
  94.                                    call the function with the symbol *)
  95.   | Rest of (string -> unit)   (** Stop interpreting keywords and call the
  96.                                    function with each remaining argument *)
  97.   | Rest_all of (string list -> unit)
  98.                                (** Stop interpreting keywords and call the
  99.                                    function with all remaining arguments *)
  100.   | Expand of (string -> string array) (** If the remaining arguments to process
  101.                                            are of the form
  102.                                            [["-foo"; "arg"] @ rest] where "foo"
  103.                                            is registered as [Expand f], then the
  104.                                            arguments [f "arg" @ rest] are
  105.                                            processed. Only allowed in
  106.                                            [parse_and_expand_argv_dynamic]. *)
  107. (** The concrete type describing the behavior associated
  108.    with a keyword. *)

  110. ‌type key = string
  111. ‌type doc = string
  112. ‌type usage_msg = string
  113. ‌type anon_fun = (string -> unit)

  115. ‌val parse :
  116.   (key * spec * doc) list -> anon_fun -> usage_msg -> unit
  117. (** [Arg.parse speclist anon_fun usage_msg] parses the command line.
  118.     [speclist] is a list of triples [(key, spec, doc)].
  119.     [key] is the option keyword, it must start with a ['-'] character.
  120.     [spec] gives the option type and the function to call when this option
  121.     is found on the command line.
  122.     [doc] is a one-line description of this option.
  123.     [anon_fun] is called on anonymous arguments.
  124.     The functions in [spec] and [anon_fun] are called in the same order
  125.     as their arguments appear on the command line.

  127.     If an error occurs, [Arg.parse] exits the program, after printing
  128.     to standard error an error message as follows:
  129. -   The reason for the error: unknown option, invalid or missing argument, etc.
  130. -   [usage_msg]
  131. -   The list of options, each followed by the corresponding [doc] string.
  132.     Beware: options that have an empty [doc] string will not be included in the
  133.     list.

  135.     For the user to be able to specify anonymous arguments starting with a
  136.     [-], include for example [("-", String anon_fun, doc)] in [speclist].

  138.     By default, [parse] recognizes two unit options, [-help] and [--help],
  139.     which will print to standard output [usage_msg] and the list of
  140.     options, and exit the program.  You can override this behaviour
  141.     by specifying your own [-help] and [--help] options in [speclist].
  142. *)

  144. ‌val parse_dynamic :
  145.   (key * spec * doc) list ref -> anon_fun -> usage_msg -> unit
  146. (** Same as {!Arg.parse}, except that the [speclist] argument is a reference
  147.     and may be updated during the parsing. A typical use for this feature
  148.     is to parse command lines of the form:
  149. -     command subcommand [options]
  150.     where the list of options depends on the value of the subcommand argument.
  151.     @since 4.01
  152. *)

  154. ‌val parse_argv : ?current: int ref -> string array ->
  155.   (key * spec * doc) list -> anon_fun -> usage_msg -> unit
  156. (** [Arg.parse_argv ~current args speclist anon_fun usage_msg] parses
  157.   the array [args] as if it were the command line.  It uses and updates
  158.   the value of [~current] (if given), or {!Arg.current}.  You must set
  159.   it before calling [parse_argv].  The initial value of [current]
  160.   is the index of the program name (argument 0) in the array.
  161.   If an error occurs, [Arg.parse_argv] raises {!Arg.Bad} with
  162.   the error message as argument.  If option [-help] or [--help] is
  163.   given, [Arg.parse_argv] raises {!Arg.Help} with the help message
  164.   as argument.
  165. *)

  167. ‌val parse_argv_dynamic : ?current:int ref -> string array ->
  168.   (key * spec * doc) list ref -> anon_fun -> string -> unit
  169. (** Same as {!Arg.parse_argv}, except that the [speclist] argument is a
  170.     reference and may be updated during the parsing.
  171.     See {!Arg.parse_dynamic}.
  172.     @since 4.01
  173. *)

  175. ‌val parse_and_expand_argv_dynamic : int ref -> string array ref ->
  176.   (key * spec * doc) list ref -> anon_fun -> string -> unit
  177. (** Same as {!Arg.parse_argv_dynamic}, except that the [argv] argument is a
  178.     reference and may be updated during the parsing of [Expand] arguments.
  179.     See {!Arg.parse_argv_dynamic}.
  180.     @since 4.05
  181. *)

  183. ‌val parse_expand:
  184.   (key * spec * doc) list -> anon_fun -> usage_msg -> unit
  185. (** Same as {!Arg.parse}, except that the [Expand] arguments are allowed and
  186.     the {!current} reference is not updated.
  187.     @since 4.05
  188. *)

  190. exception Help of string
  191. (** Raised by [Arg.parse_argv] when the user asks for help. *)

  193. exception Bad of string
  194. (** Functions in [spec] or [anon_fun] can raise [Arg.Bad] with an error
  195.     message to reject invalid arguments.
  196.     [Arg.Bad] is also raised by {!Arg.parse_argv} in case of an error. *)

  198. ‌val usage : (key * spec * doc) list -> usage_msg -> unit
  199. (** [Arg.usage speclist usage_msg] prints to standard error
  200.     an error message that includes the list of valid options.  This is
  201.     the same message that {!Arg.parse} prints in case of error.
  202.     [speclist] and [usage_msg] are the same as for {!Arg.parse}. *)

  204. ‌val usage_string : (key * spec * doc) list -> usage_msg -> string
  205. (** Returns the message that would have been printed by {!Arg.usage},
  206.     if provided with the same parameters. *)

  208. ‌val align: ?limit: int -> (key * spec * doc) list -> (key * spec * doc) list
  209. (** Align the documentation strings by inserting spaces at the first alignment
  210.     separator (tab or, if tab is not found, space), according to the length of
  211.     the keyword.  Use a alignment separator as the first character in a doc
  212.     string if you want to align the whole string.  The doc strings corresponding
  213.     to [Symbol] arguments are aligned on the next line.
  214.     @param limit options with keyword and message longer than [limit] will not
  215.     be used to compute the alignment. *)

  217. ‌val current : int ref
  218. (** Position (in {!Sys.argv}) of the argument being processed.  You can
  219.     change this value, e.g. to force {!Arg.parse} to skip some arguments.
  220.     {!Arg.parse} uses the initial value of {!Arg.current} as the index of
  221.     argument 0 (the program name) and starts parsing arguments
  222.     at the next element. *)

  224. ‌val read_arg: string -> string array
  225. (** [Arg.read_arg file] reads newline-terminated command line arguments from
  226.     file [file].
  227.     @since 4.05 *)

  229. ‌val read_arg0: string -> string array
  230. (** Identical to {!Arg.read_arg} but assumes null character terminated command
  231.     line arguments.
  232.     @since 4.05 *)


  235. ‌val write_arg: string -> string array -> unit
  236. (** [Arg.write_arg file args] writes the arguments [args] newline-terminated
  237.     into the file [file]. If any of the arguments in [args] contains a
  238.     newline, use {!Arg.write_arg0} instead.
  239.     @since 4.05 *)

  241. ‌val write_arg0: string -> string array -> unit
  242. (** Identical to {!Arg.write_arg} but uses the null character for terminator
  243.     instead of newline.
  244.     @since 4.05 *)
